markdown.markdown:
```{r} #| echo: false #| message: false library(highcharter) library(tidyverse) sizing <- function(file) { ext <- tools::file_ext(file) obj <- switch(ext, "xlsx" = read_excel(file), "xls" = read_excel(file), "csv" = read_csv(file, show_col_types = F), "rds" = read_rds(file), warning("unrecognized file extension")) size <- object.size(obj) / 1024^2 size } relabel <- function(x) { if(x$level == 2) { max_dim <- slice_max(filter(datasets, id == x$id), dimension) vars <- pull(max_dim, variables) obs <- pull(max_dim, observations) list(name = paste0( "Week: ", x$name, "
", "Variables: ", ifelse(length(vars) != 1, vars[1], vars), "
", "Observations: ", ifelse(length(obs) != 1, obs[1], obs) ), id = x$id, parent = x$parent, value = x$value, level = x$level ) } else x } ``` ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple"} We will look into the insights from past datasets in `TidyTuesday` datasets and learn how to draw treemaps using the `{highcharter}` R package powered by highchart.js. ::: We know that there are [four datasets](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2024/2024-07-02)[^1] available this week. We will mainly look at the `tt_datasets` as I am interested in **how the number of columns and that of rows affect the memory size when datasets are read into R.** [^1]: tt_summary, tt_urls, tt_variables, tt_datasets ```{r} #| label: dataset #| message: false datasets <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2024, 27, download_files = "tt_datasets.csv") head(datasets) ``` Here we define a scalable variable *dimension*, $d$: $d=n\times{m}$ where $n$ is the number of observations and $m$ is that of variables in a datasets. Then we will need to find out the object sizes when they are read into R. This is an expensive computation so here I only show the results: ```{r} #| echo: false datasets <- read_rds("../../../static/data/datasets.rds") head(datasets) ```

```{r} #| echo: false #| message: false library(highcharter) library(tidyverse) sizing <- function(file) { ext <- tools::file_ext(file) obj <- switch(ext, "xlsx" = read_excel(file), "xls" = read_excel(file), "csv" = read_csv(file, show_col_types = F), "rds" = read_rds(file), warning("unrecognized file extension")) size <- object.size(obj) / 1024^2 size } relabel <- function(x) { if(x$level == 2) { max_dim <- slice_max(filter(datasets, id == x$id), dimension) vars <- pull(max_dim, variables) obs <- pull(max_dim, observations) list(name = paste0( "Week: ", x$name, "
", "Variables: ", ifelse(length(vars) != 1, vars[1], vars), "
", "Observations: ", ifelse(length(obs) != 1, obs[1], obs) ), id = x$id, parent = x$parent, value = x$value, level = x$level ) } else x } ``` ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple"} We will look into the insights from past datasets in `TidyTuesday` datasets and learn how to draw treemaps using the `{highcharter}` R package powered by highchart.js. ::: # Datasets We know that there are [four datasets](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2024/2024-07-02)[^1] available this week. We will mainly look at the `tt_datasets` as I am interested in **how the number of columns and that of rows affect the memory size when datasets are read into R.** [^1]: tt_summary, tt_urls, tt_variables, tt_datasets ```{r} #| label: dataset #| message: false datasets <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load(2024, 27, download_files = "tt_datasets.csv") head(datasets) ``` Here we define a scalable variable *dimension*, $d$: $d=n\times{m}$ where $n$ is the number of observations and $m$ is that of variables in a datasets. Then we will need to find out the object sizes when they are read into R. This is an expensive computation so here I only show the results: ```{r} #| echo: false datasets <- read_rds("../../../static/data/datasets.rds") head(datasets) ```
